titlestmt.titleproper: Time's Up (New York, N.Y.) Records TAM 522
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tamiment staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-02-08T13:08-0500

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Time's Up is a New York City environmentalist organization whose principal activity is the promotion of bicycle riding and the rights of cyclists through its Critical Mass campaigns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This unprocessed collection has been received in several accessions, and future acessions are anticipated. Following the brief summary description, below, are inventories provided by the donor for each accession.

The collection's initial donation (2009) includes calendars, printed ephemera, including stickers; zines, legal materials, photographs, posters, including two large (approx. 36" x 12") posters, one a timeline of the organization's activities, and various photographs and realia. In 2010, thirty envelopes of photographs, taken at various Time's Up events and actions, and related events and actions, were added to the collecction, some 300-500 photographs in all, accompanied by a list of the envelope titles. An inventory, supplied by the donor, follows, below. TheIn 2011 donation contains photographs, negatives, printed ephemera (including some posters) related to various issues, events and activities. There is also a small amount of correspondence.
1. Photographs: Several envelopes of photographs, about half of them have descriptions of events or campaigns on the back.
Cars out of Central and Prospect park: 11
Time’s Up space at 49th Houston street: 14
Time’s Up Community Garden Clean Up 5th street: 12
Still we speak – rallies / Speak outs for 1st amendment right to assemble: 25
Big pictures of Reclaim The Street into Gardens avenue A. The first Reclaim The Streets in New York city in 1998, Astor Place and Broadway.
Time’s Up bicycle repair workshops, one of Simon teaching at Time’s Up’s Brooklyn space, and two of Susan teaching women-only class in Time’s Up’s Manhattan Space.

2, Calendars: Monthly calendars including garden clean-ups, bicycle rides, educational workshops, bike rides. Helped create new riders, eventually had enough bike riders to put pressure on the city for safer, greener infrastructure.

Supreme Court New York State, plaintiffs; against Time’s Up, defendants.
United States District Court, Rebecca BRAY, plaintiffs; against New-York City
Legal folders containing press releases, letter from the City of New York Police Department to Time’s Up threatening to ticket or arrest bicyclists

New York Times article backed up with photographs from Time’s Up of the police caught stealing bicycles. This incident then became the Bray case. Time’s Up provided evidence that the city was harassing and taking people’s bicycles to deter the growth of cycling during a crucial period.
